title: 115_hr6729
content: The Act titled "Empowering Financial Institutions to Fight Human Trafficking Act of 2018" allows for the provision of anti-money laundering information by financial institutions. The "Empowering Financial Institutions to Fight Human Trafficking Act of 2018" enables nonprofit organizations to share information with financial institutions, regulatory authorities, and law enforcement agencies about individuals, entities, organizations, and countries suspected of human trafficking or money laundering activities. The regulations may include procedures for cooperation and information sharing focused on identifying those involved in human trafficking, how traffickers transfer funds, and the involvement of financial institutions in such activities. The regulations aim to facilitate the identification of accounts and transactions related to human traffickers, enabling information exchange among nonprofit organizations, financial institutions, regulatory authorities, and law enforcement agencies. The regulations may align with existing programs for sharing information on unlawful activities and establish a registration process overseen by the Secretary for nonprofit organizations. The regulations require nonprofit organizations to meet specific qualifications determined by the Secretary, including implementing policies to correct inaccurate information. The Secretary can disqualify organizations that do not meet these qualifications and terminate their registration if deemed necessary. The regulations require nonprofit organizations to meet specific qualifications determined by the Secretary, including implementing policies to correct inaccurate information. Termination is appropriate with sufficient notice, registration with the Secretary is required before sharing information for safe harbor, and financial institutions are made aware of registered nonprofit organizations. The Secretary determines eligible financial institutions for information sharing. Financial institutions eligible for information sharing from nonprofit organizations must comply with regulations issued by the Secretary. This includes those already participating in existing information sharing programs. If a nonprofit organization shares information with a financial institution not eligible, it is not subject to safe harbor protection. The regulations allow financial institutions to share information on suspected unlawful activities with other institutions through existing programs. Nonprofit organizations, financial institutions, and regulatory authorities must comply with these regulations to receive safe harbor protection. Financial institutions sharing information on human trafficking or money laundering activities for identification or reporting purposes are protected from liability under US laws and regulations, except in cases where the sharing violates the law or regulations. Financial institutions sharing information on human trafficking or money laundering activities are protected from liability under US laws. Nonprofit organizations, financial institutions, and regulatory authorities are not required to demonstrate good faith when sharing information to receive safe harbor protection. Compliance with regulations under this section is not mandatory for nonprofit organizations sharing information with financial institutions or law enforcement agencies. The Secretary of the Treasury will publish reports on suspicious financial activities derived from investigations by law enforcement agencies and regulations, distributing them to financial institutions and relevant congressional committees. The Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs of the Senate defines a nonprofit organization as an entity exempt from taxation under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents for chapter 53 of title 31, United States Code. The House of Representatives passed the bill "5333. Anti-money laundering information providers" on September 26, 2018. Karen L. Haas attested to it as the Clerk.
